messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 49 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: AutoShape: An Autoencoder-Shapelet Approach for Time Series Clustering

Paper Abstract: Abstract Time series shapelets are discriminative subsequences that have been recently found effective for time series clustering (tsc). The shapelets are convenient for interpreting the clusters. Thus, the main challenge for tsc is to discover high-quality variable-length shapelets to discriminate different clusters. In this paper, we propose a novel autoencoder-shapelet approach (AutoShape), which is the first study to take the advantage of both autoencoder and shapelet for determining shapelets in an unsupervised manner. An autoencoder is specially designed to learn high-quality shapelets. More specifically, for guiding the latent representation learning, we employ the latest self-supervised loss to learn the unified embeddings for variable-length shapelet candidates (time series subsequences) of different variables, and propose the diversity loss to select the discriminating embeddings in the unified space. We introduce the reconstruction loss to recover shapelets in the original time series space for clustering. Finally, we adopt Davies–Bouldin index (DBI) to inform AutoShape of the clustering performance during learning. We present extensive experiments on AutoShape. To evaluate the clustering performance on univariate time series (uts), we compare AutoShape with 151515 representative methods using UCR archive datasets. To study the performance of multivariate time series (mts), we evaluate AutoShape on 303030 UEA archive datasets with 555 competitive methods. The results validate that AutoShape is the best among all the methods compared. We interpret clusters with shapelets, and can obtain interesting intuitions about clusters in two uts case studies and one mts case study, respectively.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 49 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 49"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Time-series clustering–a decade review",
        "Creating discriminative models for time series classification and clustering by hmm ensembles",
        "The uea multivariate time series classification archive, 2018",
        "An empirical evaluation of generic convolutional and recurrent networks for sequence modeling",
        "Interpretable clustering: an optimization approach",
        "Convex optimization",
        "The ucr time series classification archive, October 2018",
        "A cluster separation measure",
        "Statistical comparisons of classifiers over multiple data sets",
        "Efficient learning interpretable shapelets for accurate time series classification",
        "Learning time-series shapelets",
        "Information granulation-based fuzzy clustering of time series",
        "Trend-based granular representation of time series and its application in clustering",
        "Improved deep embedded clustering with local structure preservation",
        "Algorithm as 136: A k-means clustering algorithm",
        "Csmvc: A multiview method for multivariate time-series clustering",
        "A simple sequentially rejective multiple test procedure",
        "Efficient learning of timeseries shapelets",
        "Theory of point estimation",
        "Shapenet: A shapelet-neural network approach for multivariate time series classification",
        "Efficient shapelet discovery for time series classification",
        "Multivariate time series clustering based on common principal component analysis",
        "A survey of data-driven and knowledge-aware explainable ai",
        "Unsupervised feature selection using nonnegative spectral analysis",
        "Clustering of time series data—a survey",
        "A symbolic representation of time series, with implications for streaming algorithms",
        "A shapelet transform for time series classification",
        "Self-supervised time series clustering with model-based dynamics",
        "Learning representations for time series clustering",
        "Deep temporal clustering: Fully unsupervised learning of time-domain features",
        "Logical-shapelets: an expressive primitive for time series classification",
        "k-shape: Efficient and accurate clustering of time series",
        "A global averaging method for dynamic time warping, with applications to clustering",
        "Robust unsupervised feature selection",
        "Metric learning with adaptive density discrimination",
        "Facenet: A unified embedding for face recognition and clustering",
        "Robust spectral learning for unsupervised feature selection",
        "Clustering multivariate time-series data",
        "Scalable clustering of time series with u-shapelets",
        "Unsupervised deep embedding for clustering analysis",
        "Patterns of temporal variation in online media",
        "L2, 1-norm regularized discriminative feature selection for unsupervised",
        "Time series shapelets: a new primitive for data mining",
        "Time series shapelets: a novel technique that allows accurate, interpretable and fast classification",
        "Matrix profile i: all pairs similarity joins for time series: a unifying view that includes motifs, discords and shapelets",
        "Time-series generative adversarial networks",
        "Clustering time series using unsupervised-shapelets",
        "Salient subsequence learning for time series clustering",
        "A model-based multivariate time series clustering algorithm"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 49 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in AutoShape: An Autoencoder-Shapelet Approach for Time Series Clustering, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
